tr.td: Each page must have at least one main landmark, used to identify the main content.

ul.li: Most basic ARIA Landmark feature to help people identify and navigate to the main content of a web page.

tr.td: All rendered content must be placed inside of container elements with appropriate ARIA landmark roles.

ul.li: Shows that designers have considered the functional regions of their web resources.
Rule is easily fooled by placing random or creating non-functional landmarks.

tr.td: Each input, select, textarea, progress, meter and output element must have an accessible label.

ul.li: The credit card processing services used by the University do not meet pass this requirement.
This should always be 100% after all these years of being required.

tr.td: A related group of radio buttons must have a grouping label.

ul.li: Shows more advanced consideration of accessibility of forms.
Simple to implement.

tr.td: Widget elements must have keyboard event handlers.

ul.li: Indicates the lack of understanding of the keyoard support required in using ARIA widget roles.

slide.title: Limitations of Automated Checks and Implementation Scores

ul.li: At best maybe 30-40% of accessibility features can be tested automaically.
Developers are really good at figuring out how to pass automated tests without really addressing accessibility issues related to the test.

Accessibility design requires knowledge in the design and implementation stages, for example:
Landmark usage and organization.
Structural use of headings (H1-H6).
Use of color and color contrast of text content.
Keyboard navigation.
Keyboard focus styling.
How to model custom interactive web widgets with ARIA markup and keyboard event handlers.
Without knowledge and experience manual testing is difficult or impossible to evaluate.
Many important accessibility features require manual checking.
